reviews.text:
This fountain can be found in the Somorrostro beach area and I only happen to come across this while enjoying the beach.

The fountain is named in honour of Carmen Amaya, a Spanish flamenco dancer and singer, who was born in this area. I can't pretend to know much about this art form, but I read that she was described as "the greatest Spanish Romani dancer of her generation".

Given such high praise, this fountain is a sad reflection of her career. The fountain is fairly simple, with relief sculpture of figure during a dance routine featuring three dancers and two guitarists. Apart from her name cut into a nearby metal board, it's nondescript, not even something to describe her life and career.

It's okay, but don't go out of the way to see it.

Barcelona has a plethora of fountains. Many are stunningly beautiful. This is not one of them. The area around the fountain is not really one of the most desirable. The are a couple of shops around, but you would definitely not want to go out of your way to get there. Give it a miss.
The Fuente de Carmen  Amaya is not really a great reflection of this famous flamenco dancer who grew up in the streets around this area of Barcelona. Carmen would not be pleased.
If you go to Barcelonetta, the last thing you want to see is this. It is dirty and some people were sleeping near it.
